title: APT19
text: APT19 is a Chinese-based threat group targeting sectors including defense, finance, and law. Known for spearphishing and use of HTTP malware variants.

title: Ajax Security Team
text: Ajax Security Team is a group that has been active since at least 2010 and believed to be operating out of Iran. By 2014 Ajax Security Team transitioned from website defacement operations to malware-based cyber espionage campaigns targeting the US defense industrial base and Iranian users of anti-censorship technologies.

title: Agrius
text: Agrius is an Iranian threat actor active since 2020 notable for a series of ransomware and wiper operations in the Middle East, with an emphasis on Israeli targets. Public reporting has linked Agrius to Iran's Ministry of Intelligence and Security (MOIS).

title: APT-C-23
text: APT-C-23 is a threat group active since at least 2014, focused on Middle Eastern targets including Israeli military assets. It has developed mobile spyware for both Android and iOS devices since 2017, using techniques such as phishing and masquerading.

title: APT1
text: APT1 is a Chinese threat group attributed to PLA Unit 61398. It has conducted extensive cyber espionage against US entities, including the defense industrial base, and used various techniques for long-term intrusion.

title: APT12
text: APT12 is a China-attributed threat group targeting media, high-tech companies, and governments. They are known for spearphishing and using vulnerabilities in Microsoft Office and Adobe products.

title: Andariel
text: Andariel is a North Korean state-sponsored threat group active since at least 2009. It has targeted South Korean military, government, and commercial entities, and conducted cyber financial operations against ATMs, banks, and cryptocurrency exchanges. It is considered a sub-group of Lazarus Group.

title: APT30
text: APT30 is a Chinese threat group suspected to be government-backed. Known for long-term campaigns targeting Southeast Asian political entities.

title: Lazarus Group
text: Lazarus Group is a North Korean cyber threat group responsible for a wide range of cyber operations, including attacks on financial institutions, cryptocurrency exchanges, and global critical infrastructure.

title: APT16
text: APT16 is a China-based threat group that has launched spearphishing campaigns targeting Japanese and Taiwanese organizations.

title: Aoqin Dragon
text: Aoqin Dragon is a suspected Chinese cyber espionage group that has been active since at least 2013, targeting government, education, and telecom organizations in Australia, Cambodia, Hong Kong, Singapore, and Vietnam. Researchers associate it with UNC94 based on shared malware and infrastructure.

title: APT28
text: APT28 is a Russian cyber espionage group linked to the GRU's 85th Main Special Service Center. Active since at least 2004, APT28 has targeted political organizations, anti-doping agencies, nuclear facilities, and international organizations. Their operations have included hacking campaigns during the 2016 U.S. election and cyberattacks on critical infrastructure.

title: ALLANITE
text: ALLANITE is a suspected Russian cyber espionage group that has primarily targeted the electric utility sector within the United States and United Kingdom. Although similar to Dragonfly in tactics, ALLANITE has not exhibited destructive capabilities and is believed to focus on persistence and ICS process understanding.

title: APT29
text: APT29 is a Russian cyber espionage group associated with the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). It has targeted government, think tanks, and energy sectors globally using spearphishing and sophisticated malware campaigns.

title: FIN7
text: FIN7 is a financially motivated cybercrime group that primarily targets the retail, restaurant, and hospitality sectors to steal payment card information through point-of-sale malware attacks.

title: admin@338
text: admin@338 is a China-based cyber threat group. It has previously used newsworthy events as lures to deliver malware and has primarily targeted organizations involved in financial, economic, and trade policy, typically using publicly available RATs such as PoisonIvy, as well as some non-public backdoors.

title: APT17
text: APT17 is a China-based threat group that has conducted network intrusions against US government entities and major industries. They are known for abusing Microsoft TechNet for infrastructure.

title: APT18
text: APT18 is a China-attributed group active since at least 2009, targeting a wide range of industries. They have used HTTP, DNS, and various obfuscation and persistence methods.

title: APT3
text: APT3 is a China-based threat group attributed to China's Ministry of State Security. They are responsible for multiple campaigns and are known for advanced credential theft and lateral movement.

title: Cobalt Group
text: Cobalt Group is a cybercrime group specializing in attacks on financial institutions, leveraging spearphishing and malware campaigns to conduct network intrusions and financial theft.

title: APT33
text: APT33 is a suspected Iranian threat group that has carried out operations since at least 2013. The group has targeted organizations across multiple industries in the United States, Saudi Arabia, and South Korea, with a particular interest in the aviation and energy sectors.

title: APT32
text: APT32 is a suspected Vietnam-based threat group targeting Southeast Asian countries and foreign entities. They have used strategic web compromises and diverse scripting techniques for compromise and persistence.

title: APT-C-36
text: APT-C-36 is a suspected South American espionage group active since at least 2018, targeting Colombian government institutions, financial corporations, petroleum industries, and professional manufacturing.

title: Akira
text: Akira is a ransomware variant and ransomware deployment entity active since at least March 2023. Akira uses compromised credentials to access single-factor external access mechanisms such as VPNs for initial access, then various publicly-available tools and techniques for lateral movement. Akira operations are associated with 'double extortion' ransomware activity, where data is exfiltrated from victim environments prior to encryption, with threats to publish files if a ransom is not paid. Technical analysis of Akira ransomware indicates variants capable of targeting Windows or VMWare ESXi hypervisors and multiple overlaps with Conti ransomware.
